ticket.title: Titleize doesn't take all-uppercase words into account
ticket.original-body:
When using the "my string".titleize method, words which are already all-uppercase are processed like any other word. This leads to certain strings being displayed differently to how one might intend.
For example: "BLT sandwich".titleize => "Blt Sandwich" "USA today".titleize => "Usa Today"
Below is the (incredibly hacky) version I use, which first checks whether a string is all-uppercase. If it is, the string is not capitalized.
def titleize(word) words = word.split(' ') processed_words = [] words.each do |aWord| aWord = aWord.capitalize unless /^[A-Z]*$/.match(aWord) processed_words << aWord end processed_words.join(" ") end
ticket.latest-body:
When using the "my string".titleize method, words which are already all-uppercase are processed like any other word. This leads to certain strings being displayed differently to how one might intend.
For example: "BLT sandwich".titleize => "Blt Sandwich" "USA today".titleize => "Usa Today"
Below is the (incredibly hacky) version I use, which first checks whether a string is all-uppercase. If it is, the string is not capitalized.
def titleize(word) words = word.split(' ') processed_words = [] words.each do |aWord| aWord = aWord.capitalize unless /^[A-Z]*$/.match(aWord) processed_words << aWord end processed_words.join(" ") end
ticket.original-body-html:
When using the "my string".titleize method, words which are already all-uppercase are processed like any other word. This leads to certain strings being displayed differently to how one might intend.

For example: "BLT sandwich".titleize => "Blt Sandwich" "USA today".titleize => "Usa Today"

Below is the (incredibly hacky) version I use, which first checks whether a string is all-uppercase. If it is, the string is not capitalized.

def titleize(word) words = word.split(' ') processed_words = [] words.each do |aWord|

aWord = aWord.capitalize unless /^[A-Z]*$/.match(aWord)
processed_words << aWord

end processed_words.join(" ") end

version.body:
When using the "my string".titleize method, words which are already all-uppercase are processed like any other word. This leads to certain strings being displayed differently to how one might intend.
For example: "BLT sandwich".titleize => "Blt Sandwich" "USA today".titleize => "Usa Today"
Below is the (incredibly hacky) version I use, which first checks whether a string is all-uppercase. If it is, the string is not capitalized.
def titleize(word) words = word.split(' ') processed_words = [] words.each do |aWord| aWord = aWord.capitalize unless /^[A-Z]*$/.match(aWord) processed_words << aWord end processed_words.join(" ") end
version.body-html:
When using the "my string".titleize method, words which are already all-uppercase are processed like any other word. This leads to certain strings being displayed differently to how one might intend.

For example:

"BLT sandwich".titleize => "Blt Sandwich"
"USA today".titleize => "Usa Today"

Below is the (incredibly hacky) version I use, which first checks whether a string is all-uppercase. If it is, the string is not capitalized.

def titleize(word)
  words = word.split(' ')
  processed_words = []
  words.each do |aWord|
    aWord = aWord.capitalize unless /^[A-Z]*$/.match(aWord)
    processed_words << aWord
  end
  processed_words.join(" ")
end
version.title: Titleize doesn't take all-uppercase words into account

version.body:
I extended ActiveSupport to allow me to do this in a project where we had some uppercase acronyms that we wanted to maintain for various reasons. The approach is not very different from Owain's. If a string has two consecutive upcased letters, there's some funny business going on.
-jp
version.body-html:
I extended ActiveSupport to allow me to do this in a project where we had some uppercase acronyms that we wanted to maintain for various reasons. The approach is not very different from Owain's. If a string has two consecutive upcased letters, there's some funny business going on.

-jp
version.title: Titleize doesn't take all-uppercase words into account
Titleize doesn't take all-uppercase words into account

version.body:
+1 to John's patch which checks for two consecutive uppercase letters.
Helpful for the following: @@@ ruby >> "OpenID".titleize => "OpenID" >> "ActiveRecord".titleize => "Active Record" @@@
version.body-html:
+1 to John's patch which checks for two consecutive uppercase letters.

Helpful for the following:

>> "OpenID".titleize
=> "OpenID"
>> "ActiveRecord".titleize
=> "Active Record"

version.title: Titleize doesn't take all-uppercase words into account

version.body:
-1 patch applies and may be a great solution for edge cases however poses a major issue as "MY ALL CAPITALIZED STRING".titleize will output all uppercase when users input data with caps-lock which is likely to happen often.
perhaps a different solution would be to allow a config option of words to ignore in specific inflector methods?
version.body-html:
-1 patch applies and may be a great solution for edge cases however poses a major issue as "MY ALL CAPITALIZED STRING".titleize will output all uppercase when users input data with caps-lock which is likely to happen often.

perhaps a different solution would be to allow a config option of words to ignore in specific inflector methods?
version.title: Titleize doesn't take all-uppercase words into account

version.body:
I agree with steve, but I don't like the config option idea... What if we changed the patch to detect a caps-locked entry:
#pseudo-code if str == str.upcase titleize_old_way else titleize_patch_way end
That's a bit hacky, I know....but I think it'd do the trick
version.body-html:
I agree with steve, but I don't like the config option idea... What if we changed the patch to detect a caps-locked entry:

pseudo-code

if str == str.upcase
titleize_old_way else
titleize_patch_way end

That's a bit hacky, I know....but I think it'd do the trick
version.title: Titleize doesn't take all-uppercase words into account

version.body:
although the config idea sounds off, it is more likely to be backwords compatible and to cleanup all kinds of crazy things "Oops i ACCidentally CaPPitalized some stuff i wasn't supposed to", as things are less likely to be an acronym.
The inflector already has the ability for exceptions built in:
@@@ ActiveSupport::Inflector.inflections do |inflect| inflect.human /OpenID/, 'OpenID' end
@@@
problem lies in that humanize takes an underscored string, so at this point the acronym is already lost, so titelize can be modified to check inflections.humans itself, or possibly move underscore into humanize
version.body-html:
although the config idea sounds off, it is more likely to be backwords compatible and to cleanup all kinds of crazy things "Oops i ACCidentally CaPPitalized some stuff i wasn't supposed to", as things are less likely to be an acronym.

The inflector already has the ability for exceptions built in:

ActiveSupport::Inflector.inflections do |inflect|
  inflect.human /OpenID/, 'OpenID'
end

problem lies in that humanize takes an underscored string, so at this point the acronym is already lost, so titelize can be modified to check inflections.humans itself, or possibly move underscore into humanize
version.title: Titleize doesn't take all-uppercase words into account

version.body: Here's an addition to the previous patch that titleizes ALL CAPS strings.
version.body-html: Here's an addition to the previous patch that titleizes ALL CAPS strings.
version.title: Titleize doesn't take all-uppercase words into account

version.body: turns out a custom inflection option will probably need to be made and patched in as the real problem is that .capitalize is always called last and will ultimately destroy any replacements we do, so those words would need to be replaced after capitalize gets to them, or skip capetilize if ex: inflections.acronyms.included?(word)
version.body-html: turns out a custom inflection option will probably need to be made and patched in as the real problem is that .capitalize is always called last and will ultimately destroy any replacements we do, so those words would need to be replaced after capitalize gets to them, or skip capetilize if ex: inflections.acronyms.included?(word)
version.title: Titleize doesn't take all-uppercase words into account

version.body:
Great comments. My vote would be to close this ticket, leave titleize alone, and encourage developers who have edge needs such as technical or medical content to write their own titleize helper to take into account everything you gents have discussed above. titleize as it stands does as advertised.
-jp
version.body-html:
Great comments. My vote would be to close this ticket, leave titleize alone, and encourage developers who have edge needs such as technical or medical content to write their own titleize helper to take into account everything you gents have discussed above. titleize as it stands does as advertised.

-jp

version.body: @stevestmartin great comments. I'd vote to leave titleize alone for now also. This is something which would be a lot easier to solve on an individual application basis for anyone who needs it without causing unexpected results.
